events.name: GDG Auckland - September Meetup
events.description: This month Julius Spencer will be presenting a starter on Google Cloud Endpoints and Android.

events.name: GDG Auckland - October Meetup
events.description:
This month Andrew Kondratev will give a talk on porting the Apache POI XSSF library (used for accessing Excel 2007 OOXML spreadsheets) to Android. It's not a trivial process and you run into some interesting problems (see below).

Following on from this Julius Spencer will lead a general discussion about Android libraries, so have a think about your favourites and any interesting ones you've discoverd recently.

More info from Andrew:
There is not much information on reading XLSX on Android. At least one proprietary library is available with a US$1000 license for ONE application for ONE developer. What about free and open source software? Apache POI seems to be the best answer and Apache POI HSSF (Excel 97) works fine on Android, but Apache POI XSSF (Excel 2007) won’t work out of the box because of 65K methods limit and some other issues. Dynamic class loading is not the solution in this case. We’ll walk through the process of making XSSF work on Android.

events.name: GDG Auckland November Meetup
events.description:
This month +Josh Burton will talk about Recycler View, a flexible view for providing a limited window into large datasets on Android.

There will also be general discussion about the Android 5 Lollipop release, and the new Nexus devices.﻿

events.name: GDG Auckland - December 2014
events.description:
This month it's all Android content! Josh Burton will be presenting on RecyclerView (ListView2) and Julius Spencer will be presenting on Printing in Android.

As usual we'll have pizza.

events.name: GDG Auckland - February 2015 (Android with BLE Beacons, RxJava and RxAndroid)
events.description:
The year kicks off with 2 presentations related to Android!

1) John Graves will be presenting on Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) and Beacons.

2) Robin Stark will be presenting an introduction to RxJava and RxAndroid.

Look forward to seeing you there!

events.name: GDG Auckland - March 2015
events.description:
TBA

NB we are are at Hapara's new office this month, Level 10, 99 Queen Street.

events.name: GDG Auckland - April 2015
events.description:
This month is all about Libraries!

Libraries for Android, App Engine, Cloud Endpoints, Maps, Polymer etc. Bring along your favourite cache of libraries so we can all discuss and learn what people are using / moving to / dropping.

See you there!

events.name: GDG Auckland - May - Android Automated Testing
events.description:
Hi everyone,

This month Bede Ngaruko is going to take us through  Android Automated Testing. Demos will be in Appium and/or Espresso.

We hope to see you there with your testing and other questions / experience.

With Google IO not far away, we are looking for volunteers to do a 5 minute presentation on one part of IO. This would occur at a special meeting 25th June. Please get in contact if you would be willing to present.

events.name: June - IO and Dagger 2 for Android!
events.description:
This month we'll start a little earlier and have a quick catch up about Google IO before Adam takes us through Dagger 2.

"Dagger 2 is a complete rewrite of the successful dependency injection framework for Java and Android that provides a completely compile-time generated implementation of the entire object graph. By generating code that is normal, non-reflective Java, Dagger 2 provides a solution that is simple, traceable, performant and designed to maximize developer velocity." 

At this talk, we'll explore how Dagger handles Dependency Injection, the different features of Dagger 2, and how to build your next app with modular design using Dagger 2. 

About Adam: 

Adam McNabb - Software Developer, Fiserv. 

B. Sc. Software Development 

B. Sc. Digital Media 

American Refugee :)

events.name: GDG Auckland - June/July - IO Recap!
events.description:
This meetup we have 4 volunteers who will be doing a shallow dive into something new that came out of IO.

John Graves - Voice Access

Simon Buxton - Google Photos

Sam Freeman - The Android Design Support Library

Julius Spencer - App Linking + Permissions Changes

Thanks to the volunteers for stepping up for this event! If you would like to contribute and do a 10 minute presentation on something from IO, let us know.

Presentations will start at 7pm.

events.name: Android Auto
events.description:
In August Julius Spencer is going to take us through his travels with Android Auto, specifically what it takes to integrate a media application with Auto and test it out.

We will also have time for members who would like to demonstrate their applications. So polish them up and bring them along!

This may be the last meetup for Simon Buxton for a while as he heads overseas. So don't miss the opportunity to catch up with him before he leaves.

Look forward to seeing you there!

events.name: Google Appengine
events.description:
John Graves will be taking us through some of his experiences with AppEngine.

Apps today frequently involve some connection to data in the cloud, so understanding how the app and back end can be "co-architected" can be good to know about.

We look forward to seeing you there. There is an open invitation to demo your applications too. Just let us know on arrival.

Julius is also trying out a demo Nearby application. You can download it on the night.

events.name: Firebase and Android Announcements
events.description:
This month we have Adrian Wills talking about his experience building a server application with Firebase with a number of clients accessing it. 

"Firebase can power your app's backend, including data storage, user authentication, static hosting, and more."

Julius Spencer will show a little example code of the Firebase Android client working with a Firebase application.

In addition we will be looking at some of the announcements which we are likely to hear on the 30th (NZT).

events.name: Cordova and Auto-backup for Android Apps
events.description:
This month John Graves is going to take us through his experiences using Cordova to make mobile applications.

In additions Julius is going to take a tour of using the new backup feature in Android 6.0 that allows developers to simply backup user's app data and restore it.

events.name: TensorFlow and Android Dev Summit
events.description:
Being the Christmas we'll likely have a good amount of time to catch up with one another however…

John couldn't let the open sourcing of TensorFlow go un-reported so he is going to give a presentation on it.

In addition we thought we'd take a look at some of the announcements from the Android Dev Summit. 

Remember that devmob is on next weekend (5th / 6th). Don't miss out!

events.name: Playing with a Playground App and From Zero to AppEngine in Hours
events.description:
Please note that this year, GDG will be on the first Wednesday of each month!


From Zero to AppEngine in Hours

by Alan Ansell

Starting with a fun idea for using Bluetooth beacons for time tracking, Alan built an app and an AppEngine backend for storing and sharing the data in a matter of hours.  2013 article about Alan


Playing with a Playground App

by Dr. Stefan Schliebs

Need to find a place to play with your toddler? Stefan did, so he built an app to help solve the problem.

events.name: Android Fingerprint first impressions and building an Android Conservation App
events.description:
This month we have two seasoned Android developers sharing their experiences.

Nic Tolentino is going to go through his experience developing and deploying apps on devices without network connectivity, a conservation app case study.

In addition Liam Heneghan is going to take us through his impressions working with the Android Fingerprint APIs new in Marshmallow.

Look forward to seeing you there.

events.name: Android application architecture / Kotlin and Android N Preview
events.description:
Sergey Buzin is presenting about application architecture to improve the speed of development and bug fixing as well as some discussion about the Kotlin programming language.

In addition there will be some time to go through some of the Android N features and other Android news.

This will be the last meetup before IO; look out for an announcement for an Extended IO meetup coming soon!

events.name: I/O Extended 2016 Auckland
events.description:
Join us for an Extended I/O 2016!

Come watch the keynote and a number of sessions with us and join in some lively discussion about the announcements.

The current plan is for people to arrive around 4:50am, just in time for the keynote. We'll have breakfast food, drinks and snacks available throughout the event, but feel free to contribute with some food or drink. As there will be various live streams to choose from, we'll be deciding what to watch on the day. For more information about what talks will be available during the event please refer to https://events.google.com/io2016/schedule#day1. Also, note that we'll be unable to host live streams after 11am.

- 4:50am - 5am People arrive

- 5am - 7am Live stream: Keynote

- 7am - 8am Break - Keynote discussion, Google news, live stream?

- 8am - 9am Live stream: What's new in Android

- 9am - 10am Live stream: Choice of videos to watch

- 10am - 11am Live stream: Choice of videos to watch

We will also have an Android TV, Android Wear, Nexus 9 running Android-N preview and Cardboard to play with.

There is limited space so please RSVP early to avoid missing out!

There are rumours of swag / spot prizes.

events.name: Firebase and IO2016 Recap
events.description:
What a month; seems like Google is on fire!

This month:

An IO Overview; consumer and dev announcements aplenty!

A Firebase overview with demos by John Graves.

April / May news brought to you by Nic Tolentino.

We have an OnHub too, which will be available to look at.

Look forward to seeing everyone. Remember we're on Level 4 now.

events.name: Android TV and the Leanback UI plus Android developer resources
events.description:
Developing and designing for Android TV and the Leanback UI

This month Damian Karzon will be joining us to take us through developing for Android TV and the Leanback UI. How do these apps differ from standard Android apps and what kind of UI design patterns do we need to be aware of for these devices? Also we'll have a look at the code behind an Android TV app and check out some helpful tools and libraries for building your TV apps.

Overview of Android developer resources

Learn which Google IO videos are worth watching, what the best websites are for API documentation, material design and UI implementation, keeping up to date with the latest news and libraries as well as podcasts, Youtube channels, tutorials and a whole lot more! This talk should be suitable for beginner and advanced Android developers alike.

We'll also have the standard monthly news brought to you by Nic Tolentino.

events.name: Android Daydream and Chrome Web Store
events.description:
Android Daydream

Daydream is a platform for high quality mobile virtual reality. This month Nic is going to take us through some initial findings with Daydream on Android.

Chrome Web Store

Julius is going to take us through deploying a Chrome App and demonstrate some Android applications running on Chrome OS.

We look forward to catching up!

events.name: The Model View Presenter pattern and Implementing Bottom Navigation in Android
events.description:
Implementing Bottom Navigation in Android

Learn all about the joys of implementing a stateful bottom navigation bar (https://material.google.com/components/bottom-navigation.html) in Android using nothing but the support library and a slightly masochistic personality.

Nic Tolentino

The Model View Presenter pattern

The Android framework offers a lot of flexibility when it comes to defining how to organise and architect an Android app. This freedom, whilst very valuable, can also result in apps with large classes, inconsistent naming and architectures (or lack of) that can make testing, maintaining and extending difficult. At this talk, we will explore how MVP (Model View Presenter) design pattern helps to solve the common problems while making the code more maintainable, extensible and unit testable.

Sourabh Gupta

We look forward to seeing you; this time on the 2nd Wednesday of the month!

events.name: Made By Google
events.description:
Join us for the Made By Google event!

Start your Wednesday early by ending the speculation, rumour and hearsay with an early morning catch up which includes Hash browns, Coffee, Juice and other developers*!

Rumours** include:

Pixel phones, Pixel tablets, Pixel watches, 4k Google cast, Google home, Android 7.1, Daydream specs and Andromeda (Android + ChromeOS merge) and so much more…

* Developers not for consumption

** GDG Auckland can not be held responsible for any excit-o-meter malfunctions as a result of listed "Rumours"

events.name: Dart and Made by Google
events.description:
Paul Sanderson is going to give a background of what Dart is, how it has developed since he started using it in 2013 to where it is now and where it is going (e.g Fuchsia). In addition he is going to go through a quick example of how quick it is to get an Angular 2 dart app going and some of the advantages it has over Typescript and Javascript. We may even glimpse some Flutter code!

Nic Tolentino will be bringing us an overview of all the announcements made at the recent MadeByGoogle event such as the new Pixel phones, Daydream View headset, Google home and much more! 

Finally, there will also be a recap of the developer and consumer news that has occurred over the past month. So much going on!

events.name: Tensorflow in the Cloud and Task-locking Android Apps
events.description:
This month John Graves will take us through Tensorflow in the Cloud and some pointers in getting started with Google Cloud Machine Learning.

Julius will take us briefly through taking an application and task-locking it for kiosk uses.

Look forward to seeing you there!

events.name: Refactoring a FragmentPagerAdapter with Kotlin
events.description:
This month Matt Clarke is going to take us through a small, practical example of how Kotlin's features can be leveraged to achieve the DRY principle and reduce boilerplate code with something most Android developers will be familiar with - a custom FragmentPagerAdapter.

In addition, Nic will take us through highlights of some news and there will be lots of time to catch up with everyone pre-Christmas.

events.name: Android Things and Applying Lessons Learned From A Code Retreat
events.description:
This month we're fortunate to have Alix Klingenberg who will be running through some interesting ideas about designing code for extension and adaptability, with practical examples in Java in an Android context.

Also, Nic Tolentino will be taking us through getting started with Android Things with a Raspberry Pi 3B.

We look forward to seeing you!

events.name: Cloud Next - Day 1 and 2
events.description:
The Google Cloud Next conference is scheduled for the 8th to the 10th of March (PST). We're planning to host people for a 6am start on the 9th and 10th of March.

The keynote speakers announced so far include: Diane Greene, Sundar Pichai and Eric Schmidt.

Join us for announcements and some light refreshments.

If we there is interest, we will run a codelab.

events.name: Android O and Android Things Automatic Doorbell
events.description:
https://assets.pcmag.com/media/images/536396-android-o.jpg?thumb=y&width=405&height=228

Android O

With the release of the Android O preview we are going to take a quick run through some of what is likely to change for users and developers.

Android Things Automatic Doorbell

This month we are going to demo the Android Things Doorbell application which takes a photo and sends it up to Firebase to display on a companion application. We'll take it a bit further to automate the process using a PIR sensor.

We'll also have our usual spot of other Google related news and rumours section.

Look forward to seeing you there!

events.name: I/O Extended 2017 Auckland
events.description:
Google I/O is coming to Auckland! 

Hot off the heels of the biggest Android event of the year, we'll be running our own Google I/O Extended!

We're combining with Auckland Android Community to make this a great event. You don't want to miss this! Note: The location will be at Grid AKL.

Stay tuned for the confirmed lineup, but you can expect codelabs, our own fireside chat with IO attendees, and more.

See you there!

events.name: Kotlin Tips and Tricks and App Shortcuts
events.description:
This month we have 2 great Android talks lined up.

Kotlin Tips and Tricks by Peter Ho

Kotlin has taken the Android world by storm - who wouldn't want to learn some tips and tricks from a seasoned developer?

About Peter Ho

Peter has over 4 years experience working on Android, and works on a number of production apps using Kotlin, including Neighbourly.

Android App Shortcuts by Dan Lee

App Shortcuts help your users get where they need to go faster! Find out how to implement them.

About Dan Lee

Dan Lee is a Junior Android Engineer working at Pushpay. Dan works on both Android and React Native, and has recently implemented App Shortcuts in the Pushpay app.

Doors open at 6:00pm and the talks will kick off around 6:30pm. Come along early for drinks and pizza.

events.name: Dependency Injection and Function Currying on Kotlin
events.description:
Dependency Injection! Need we say any more folks? And Function Currying on Kotlin, heard about that? Wonder no more! Join us for two more super exciting talks by two great speakers this month: 


Dagger-Android (A Knife in the Dark), by Konstantin Tchernov, Senior Android Dev at Xero. 

Dependency Injection is often either underused or a source of bewilderment. It doesn't need to be like that! New additions to Dagger 2 that came out this year take us a long way to getting you going with a readable, testable and maintainable code with fewer tears. Live coding included, bring popcorn.

Introduction to Function Currying in Kotlin, by Rick Chen, Mobile Dev Chapter Lead at Trade Me.

A short exploration around an function currying in Kotlin: what it is, why it is interesting, and how you can use it in Android and elsewhere!

We will start at 6:00 PM. As usual there will be pizzas and drinks.

events.name: Retrofit and AndroidThings
events.description:
This month we have presentations on Retrofit and AndroidThings.

Extending Retrofit for fun and profit! 

by Matt Clarke, Senior Software Engineer at Orion.

Matt will run us through a real-world example of how Retrofit can be extended with custom behaviour to solve app-wide problems.

Building with AndroidThings and Arduino

by Julius Spencer, Android developer at JSA.

Julius is going to demonstrate and take us through some highlights (and lowlights) of his journey building a hardware and software project to collect and chart data using Arduino and AndroidThings.

We will start at 6:00 PM. As usual, there will be pizzas and drinks.

events.name: Pixels and Mobile Center
events.description:
Hi everyone! Apologies for keeping you waiting on this one, but we were just gathering the latest and greatest things for this meetup (as always!)

We will kick-off with "Extended Pixel Reveal" by Nic Tolentino.

A brief overview of the latest products by Google and their implications for developers. What's available for us, how do we gear up for what's coming and how do we make the most of what was announced.

And then, we will head out to "Continuous Everything using Visual Studio Mobile Center".

Take the “work” out of workflow and get faster release cycles and more time to focus on features! Sourabh Gupta from Debitsuccess will show how we can connect Android to Visual Studio Mobile Center’s continuous integration, automated testing, distribution, monitoring, and engagement capabilities.

As usual, there will be pizzas and drinks for added fun.

events.name: MPAndroidChart and MapMe
events.description:
NOTE the change of venue!  We are meeting at JSA, Level 4, 220 Queen Street.

This month we have two interesting talks on a couple of awesome Android libraries.

David Rawson, Android Developer at Fisher & Paykel Healthcare – Data visualisation in Android using MPAndroidChart

David will take us through setting up a basic chart through to some heavyweight customisation.


Josh Burton, Senior Android Developer for Trade Me Property – MapMe Library

Josh is going to take us through a brief look at his MapMe library.

NOTE the change of venue!  We are meeting at JSA, Level 4, 220 Queen Street.

We look forward to catching up! 🍕

events.name: DialogFlow plus See New Things and Act
events.description:
Holiday season is almost upon us so we'll have two short talks this month which will give us a bit more time to catch up.

Dr. John Graves of Qrious is going to take us through an introduction to Google's Chatbot Builder as well as Understanding Google's Big Data Superpowers.

If you have a project you'd like to share or demo we will have time for anyone who would like to.

We look forward to seeing you for some pizza and drink!

events.name: Android Fireside Chat
events.description:
• What we'll do
We're kicking off the New Year with something a little bit different - our very own Android Fireside Chat!

We've put together a panel of Android devs from around Auckland to answer your questions.

Curious about workflow? How Dagger is implemented? Which CI service to use? Or looking for some great library recommendations?

Now's your chance!

Get thinking about any questions you'd like to ask and add them to this event: https://app2.sli.do/event/ntb9zu66/ask

Our panelists are:

* Peter Ho - Independent
* Sara Metz - Trade Me
* Julius Spencer - JSA
* Konstantin Tchernov - Xero
* Matt Clarke - Genesis Energy

Be there from 6pm @ Trade Me for pizza and drinks. See you there!

• What to bring

• Important to know
Make sure you add your questions to the event form: https://app2.sli.do/event/ntb9zu66/ask

events.name: The Atlassian Pipeline for Android Development and Escapades with Android Things
events.description:
• What we'll do
This month we have a couple of interesting talks: The Atlassian Pipeline for Android Development and Escapades with Android Things.

Sergey Buzin, software engineer at Blerter, is sharing his knowledge on using Atlassian Pipeline for Android and deploying to slack, play store and fabric. Liam Heneghan, software developer at JSA, is taking us through a demo and some code of a recent project using Android Things.

We look forward to catching up! 🍕

• What to bring

• Important to know

events.name: Introduction to Architecture Components and Visual Studio App Center
events.description:
• What we'll do
We've got 2 more great talks lined up this month:

Introduction to Android Architecture Components by Franco Sabadini

Visual Studio App Center by Tommy Alsemgeest

Come on down to The Grid at 6pm for drinks and pizzas before we kick off!

• What to bring

• Important to know

events.name: IO18 Keynote
events.description:
The IO18 keynote Material will set your heart a Flutter… especially if you join us at 5 am!

Come along for juice, coffee, toast so we can all share in our react-tions to the announcements.

This is part of the extended events which are happening all over the world.

events.name: Go and I/O Extended
events.description:
We've got something a little different this month!

We're going to have a few talks from a few members about the developer announcements from the recently concluded Google I/O, plus some Android swag to give away!

Also, don't miss Taco de Wolff, a software engineer at TixTrack NZ, who is sharing his knowledge on Go (https://golang.org/); its use-cases, its tooling, strengths, and weaknesses.

Come by and have a chat with those who attended I/O and share those things you found most interesting. We'll also have an AndroidThings kit on display.

events.name: Bitrise CI, From Developer to Solution Architect
events.description:
Apologies for the delay in the announcement:

Brave that Auckland weather and come on down to GridAKL for another great night.

We're lucky to have Bitrise sponsor this month's meetup!

Come along for this great lineup:

Bitrise CI
Josh Burton

From Developer to Solution Architect
Yu Bin

How I built this
Franco Sabadini

This month we're starting a new segment - How I built this. This segment is where you can show off what you've built, without needing to do a full-blown presentation.

See you there!

events.name: Flutter Study Jam
events.description:
Flutter is new and interesting to many of the community so to help you get off the ground we're going to get together for a Study Jam to work through the first two Udacity classes.

Come along and join in the fun as we learn together and get started making things with Flutter.

If you can, bring a device with an IDE (Android Studio / IntelliJ or Visual Studio Code) installed. If you're feeling adventurous, install Flutter (https://flutter.io/get-started/install/) before you arrive.

We'll have some snacks and drinks so bring along your chopsticks!

events.name: Serverless Tools for Mobile/Web Backends, Machine Learning, and Big Data
events.description:
Join us for an amazing talk by Google Developer Advocate Bret McGowen. He'll be taking us through serverless tools for mobile/web backends, machine learning, and big data. His talk will cover a lot of offerings from Google Cloud Platform, and the examples will be in NodeJS.

This event is going to be amazing, so make sure to RSVP soon - you don't want to miss out on this one!

We'll kick off at 6pm with a drink and some food, with the talk beginning at 6:30pm.

Hope to see you all there!

events.name: Shoot for the Stars: Getting more user reviews and app ratings
events.description:
Don't miss our October meetup!

This month we have a really interesting talk by Rick Chen:

Shoot for the Stars: Getting more user reviews and a quick boost to our app ratings

Rick will talk about how we got more user ratings and reviews for Trade Me Property with the users' interests in mind.

We'll also have a lightning talk by Josh Burton:
My favourite Android library - Airbnb Epoxy

Come along from 6pm for drinks and pizza.

Also, we have updated speakers and schedule for the DevFest 🎉 happening in under a month! Get your tickets now: https://akldevfest.gdg.nz/

events.name: DevFest Auckland 2018
events.description:
DevFest is coming to Auckland, November 9th!

Register now through our website: https://akldevfest.gdg.nz/

We have Googlers, Google Developer Experts and more presenting at this one day event.

DevFest is a community-run developer event focused on community building and learning about Google’s technologies.

Look out for exciting talks on a range of topics, including:
Android Things, Kotlin, Flutter; Google Cloud Platform (GCP) and Firebase; Machine Learning plus more to come.

events.name: Koin and AndroidX
events.description:
Don't miss our final meetup for the year!

We know December is a busy month but we've got 2 great talks lined up to finish off the year:

Migrating to AndroidX - Vikas Singh
Vikas will talk about his experience migrating an app to use AndroidX.

Koin - Matt Clarke
This will be a practical, beginner-friendly introduction to Koin, a lightweight dependency injection framework for Kotlin, which seems to offer the same kinds of boilerplate-reduction as the move from Java to Kotlin.

Come along for drinks and pizza from 6pm.

events.name: Intro to Flutter
events.description:
GDG Auckland are kicking off the year with an intro to Flutter!

You've probably heard the hype about Google's shiny new mobile development cross-platform toolkit. Come hear from Lance Johnstone, a software developer at Auror, about his experiences getting started with Flutter and how it compares to other cross-platform options.

Join us for some beer and pizza after the talk to connect and start the year on a good note!

A bit about Lance:
Lance is classically a C# .Net dev who moved into lead and architecture roles in recent years with more of a focus around delivering mobile solutions to banks and financial institutions.
Now helping Auror be an awesome place and make an awesome product.

events.name: Women Techmakers on their Unconventional Tech Journey
events.description:
GDG Auckland is excited to launch our Women Techmakers program! We're joining the amazing Google community of other Women Techmakers https://www.womentechmakers.com/

For our first event, we're partnering with the Women in Tech Auckland group! We have some amazing speakers lined up who will be sharing with us their non conventional path into the Tech industry and some of their key learnings. Everyone is welcome at this event - you don't need to be part of the Women Techmakers community to attend.

Keep an eye out on the page as the speakers will be announced over the next few days!

The event will take place at 6:00 p.m. on Thursday, Feb 28, at Xero in central Auckland. Doors close at 6:30pm.

Our amazing hosts at Xero have provided a safe space for children to hang out, if you'd like to bring your kids along. (Please note you will still be responsible for supervising them.) They do not count towards the attendee limit.

We value the participation of each member of our community and want all attendees to have an enjoyable and fulfilling experience. Please familiarise yourself with our Code of Conduct (http://www.meetup.com/Women-in-Tech-Meetup-Auckland/pages/Code_of_Conduct/) ahead of attending a Women in Tech meetup.

We look forward to seeing you there!

---
Note regarding attendance:

RSVPs usually fill up very quickly but only about 50% of people attend. As this event is promoted in partnership across the GDG and Women in Tech Meetup groups, we will be accepting the first people who come to the event, and having RSVP'd is not a guarantee of entry. We apologise for the inconvenience, but our priority is ensuring that the most people can attend.

events.name: Hack Night
events.description:
One of our favourite things to do is to work on our own side projects. We're going to get together to work on whatever we want for a few hours!

Join us to hang out, work on your stuff, chat to other like-minded developers and maybe have a slice of pizza. If you're stuck on a tricky problem, we'll have people with a range of experiences - from Android to Flutter to C# to Cloud development - who can help you figure it out.

Bring your own laptop and mobile devices - we'll provide the internet connection.

Everyone welcome - we hope to see you all there!
events.how_to_find_us: Catch the lift up to Level 1 - if you can't get in, message Julius Spencer on here

events.name: Flutter Tips
events.description:
Hi GDGers 👋

This month we've got a talk on Flutter Tips with a whole range of bits and pieces we've picked up to help with your development. Topics include: favourite libraries, IDE tricks, information sources, deployment and proxying network traffic. We'd love to hear what you've learnt along the way so bring along your tips to share with the group as well!

Nic will be giving us a lightning talk ⚡️ on the latest Google announcements too. 🎮

In case you missed it, we recently had a hack night which was fun; it was great to see people getting back into projects and helping one another out. Look out for the announcement of the next one soon.

We're looking forward to catching up with you over some snacks and drinks from 6pm on Level 1.

events.name: Google IO Extended Developer Keynote
events.description:
Do you enjoy the warm embrace of your blankets in the morning? Consider yourself more of a night owl than an early bird? Just want to sleep in a bit this year instead of waking up at ridiculous o'clock to watch the IO keynotes? Well have we got the event for you!

Join a bunch of friendly, like-minded people in hanging out and watching a replay of the developer keynote after work!

- 6:30pm Introductions, pizza and drinks
- 6:45pm Replay of Developer Keynote
- 7:45pm Impressions and discussions of keynote and other IO talks / announcements

Don't forget to check out the official IO schedule for details on what talks will be going on throughout the day https://events.google.com/io/schedule/events/

Looking forward to seeing you!

events.name: I/O 2019 Recap
events.description:
Information overload? 🤯 Not to worry; over the next few months we're hosting events to recap some of the content from I/O to help.

This month we have a number of lightning talks on:
- Jetpack Compose
- Navigation changes in Android
- Flutter for Web

Matt Clarke is going to give us a quick run-down on what Jetpack Compose is and how it could change how you create your UI in Android.

Julius Spencer is going to summarise the upcoming changes to Android’s navigation and what it means to design and implementation of your screens.

Nic Tolentino will cover what Flutter for Web means and how it you can get started, along with current caveats.

Looking forward to seeing you there and a reminder that we are hosting (https://www.meetup.com/GDGAuckland/events/261117378/) the worldwide Flutter hack day (https://flutterhackathon.com) coming up on the 1st June.

GDG Auckland

events.name: Flutter Hack19
events.description:
Join us in a full day of hacking together using Flutter. Work with a team of 2 to 4 people, to build fun, unusual, interesting, or helpful projects which could go on to change the world - or at least win you a prize 😉

This hackathon is part of an international Flutter event, so there will be swag, and live coverage, as well as prizes for the most popular projects.

Schedule (subject to change):
10:00am - Kickoff / topic revealed / team forming
10:30am - Coding
12:00am - Lunch
12:01pm - More coding
4:30pm - Upload code / prepare presentations
5:00pm - Presentations / voting / prize giving

Lunch will be provided, as well as snacks and drinks throughout the day

We'll provide more details of the event as we get closer to the date but check out https://flutterhackathon.com for general event details.

Update: Please ensure that on the day you bring a laptop with the Flutter SDK and IDE and emulator (or device) installed, this will save everyone a lot of time and hassle. Check out this link that will guide you through the process https://flutter.dev/docs/get-started/install/windows

Update: Please arrive slightly before 10am as we are planning to start on time.

events.name: Hack Night
events.description:
After the great feedback from our last hack night we've decided to host another to work on those side projects for a few hours.

Join us to hang out, work on your stuff, get some help, chat with other developers and have some sushi and snacks. If you're stuck on a tricky problem, we'll have people with a range of experiences - from Android to Flutter to web development - who can help you figure it out.

Bring your own laptop and mobile devices - we'll provide the Internet connection.

Everyone welcome - we hope to see you all there!

events.name: Jetpack Navigation and Kotlin extension functions
events.description:
This month we're hosting a shared event with the Auckland Android Meetup group. It's gonna be great event with talks on Jetpack Navigation and Kotlin stdlib extension functions.

Jetpack Navigation
Tommy Alsemgeest

This talk is all about Jetpack Navigation - how to use it, what are SafeArgs, and how it differs from conventional navigation.

.let{s} .also repeat() .run with() .apply
Nic Tolentino

Who doesn't love extension functions? In this talk we'll go over some best practices around using them, as well as use cases for the Kotlin's standard scope functions, followed by a breakdown of how they're implemented and a suggestion for how one might go about creating their own, to better handle null values (suitable for beginner to intermediate Kotlin developers).

Trade Me will be providing the venue, as well as drinks/pizza from 6pm. We look forward to seeing you there!

events.name: Automating Software Delivery with Spinnaker
events.description:
Spinnaker, developed jointly by Google and Netflix, is an open-source multi-cloud continuous delivery platform.

Join us this month with Ryan Cartwright to learn how Spinnaker can enable your engineering teams to work more efficiently and produce more output so your business can innovate faster.

Spinnaker is being chosen by a growing number of enterprises as the open-source continuous deployment platform used to modernise their application deployments. Most of these enterprises deploy applications to multiple clouds. One of Spinnaker’s features is its ability to allow you to deploy applications to different clouds using best practices and proven deployment strategies.

Doors will open at 18:00, and the presentation will run from 18:30 to 19:30.

events.name: Kotlin Codelabs Session
events.description:
👋To help those making the migration to Kotlin, we're running a codelabs session where you can come along and work through a couple of codelabs together. We will have a number of people to help run the session so you won't get stuck.

To help us prepare, please vote on your the codelabs you'd most like to do at the following link:
https://www.meetup.com/GDGAuckland/polls/1283881/

We're running this on a Saturday so that there won't be time pressures. If you're already experiences and would like to help the community please get in touch as well.

events.name: Flutter - Interact and Provider
events.description:
This month our meetup is Flutter focused.

We'll be reviewing announcements from the Flutter Interact event as well as hearing a short talk about Provider, the state management library for Flutter.

Jarrod Lodge from Lime Digital has been using it on a couple of projects and will give a short overview and share his experiences.

There will also be time to catch up beforehand and meet with the community. Look forward to seeing you!

upcoming.name: Dependency Injection, Super optimisation and Mem Leaks.
upcoming.description:
Let's kick off the new year with a few drinks, pizzas and two great Android talks! 🍕

Nic Tolentino, from Trade Me, will have a presentation on Dependency Injection!

This presentation will give us an overview of dependency injection. And a comparison of available libraries: Dagger, Dagger-Android, Koin, and Toothpick.

Wildrich Fourie, from ASB, will talk about those nasty mem leaks and how to super optimise our code.

This talk will look at common Android memory leaks and how to avoid or fix them. Also, it will look at aggressive code optimisation recommendations.

We'll kick off at 6pm with a drink and some food, with the talk beginning at 6:30pm.

See you then!

organizers.name: Vikas S.
organizers.bio: I'm into s/w dev, mostly mobile apps for different platforms. Doing a lot of Android and React lately.

group_profile.intro: Mobile dev, mostly doing Android and React Native.
Interested in how technology can make a difference
